title: Mid-week murk clinging to southeastern Australia
content:
Anthony Duke, 
			
			Wednesday September 9, 2015 - 14:54 EST  

			Fog and low cloud was extensive this morning across New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria leading to a murky start to the day and there is more to come. 

Cobar airport had a real pea-souper with visibility dropping as low as 100 metres early this morning. Similarly, Griffith airport in the Riverina and Kilmore Gap had visibility as low as 250 metres. Low cloud and drizzle this morning at Adelaide reduced visibility to as low as 1500 metres around 8am, making driving conditions a little dicey. 

The reason for the foggy conditions was the persistent southwesterly airflow drawing humid air across a broad area of the country. High pressure over the area aided in the fog development overnight as winds became light. 

Generally high pressure is synonymous with fair weather, but with so much moisture being drawn up from the Southern Ocean, the high acts to trap the moisture near the surface. 

Over the next couple of nights the high is expected to shift further east over southeastern Australia. This will lead to more light winds overnight and continued trapping over moisture leading to extensive mist and fog in SA, TAS, VIC and inland NSW. As the high shifts east later in the week, warm and dry air will be drawn south, reducing the fog risk.
